headline: Minnesota Senate candidate slams probe of Rep. Keith Ellison; are Democrats using delaying tactics against Kavanaugh?
subHeadline: Guests: Tammy Bruce, Marjorie Clifton, Jonathan Turley, Sen. Tom Cotton, Rochelle Ritchie, Michael Anton, Karin Housley

utterances.sentences: Well-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

Or are we for that? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

But -- but -- but we-- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.sentences: No, I'm not actually --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You're saying, but hold on, yes, you are--

utterances.sentences: --no.

utterances.sentences: No. What I'm--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: Well what I'm -- what I'm going to tell you is that the workforce was largely built by white Christian men. And that's not a bad thing. It's just the reality. And businesses are seeing this that when they think diversity --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, hold on, I'm sorry, you can't keep going with that explaining because I'm -- I'm not following. I'm not tracking. And I'm not just playing games--

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: --I am explaining.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I don't get it.

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Why -- so the race of the people sitting in the Senate matters because why?

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: The gender I would say even more in this case because--

utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and are verifiable. They're reflected in DNA. We don't believe that about race though, do we? Do we think that certain races have more wisdom or more honesty than others?

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: No, of course not. Of course not.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. Well of course not, then why is the race relevant at all?

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: Well I think it's creating a larger conversation about diversity and who's at leadership and what --

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: I did not endorse that. But what I would say is that there it is erupting a lot of unhelpful conversations that are related but not about this particular trial. So, but I think--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Would it be fair to say to someone who attacks white men you're not allowed to attack people on the basis of their skin color ever? Period. And if you don't like the --

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --attacks on other races, don't attack a race, is that OK?

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Absolutely, I -- I--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. So, you'd say that to Bill Maher and April Ryan and all these other dumb people who are going on with these racist attacks, it's OK to call them out?

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I wouldn't have a conversation that way. But I -- what I would say is that when you -- when I'm talking about representation is that companies even see this in terms of productivity. When they increase diversity in their leadership by 10 percent, they see a 1 percent increase in earnings. That's just the -- that's the productivity and the reality so there's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, that's not actually a real statistic. It's a made-up statistic, and it's much more complicated than that --

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: By Mackenzie Consulting that --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --I wish we had time you can come back to--

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: I would love that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --to throw that statistic at me.

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I would love that.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't even know what diversity means. But whatever, thank you.

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: It means non-White men and that's what -- and that's what's hard--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, is that what it means?

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: --and -- and well let me be clear--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: I was raised by a white Christian man. And -- and he very much understands and sees--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: --issues from a different way like you, Tucker, who is a father of many daughters and as we go into the workforce as we experienced what that's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. Well I'm just -- I'm just amazed that we're all racists now. I thought we weren't but I guess we are--

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: That's not -- but that's not me calling anyone--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --no, we are. We're attacking people--

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: --racist.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --well we're attacking people on their race, so you're racist now- -

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: --no, what we are -- no, what we are is--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right. We can call whatever we want.

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: --what we are, are human beings who--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --we're all George Wallace.

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: --well, no--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. Well I'm out of time unfortunately--

utterances.speaker: CLIFTON
utterances.sentences: --no, we will --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it's a sickening conversation. But I appreciate your taking part. Arizona prosecutor, Rachel Mitchell, has prepared a memo for Senate Republicans expressing her beliefs about Christine Ford's allegations after last week's hearings. In that memo, she says Ford's case -- Ford's case is even weaker than he said, she said and that no reasonable prosecutor would press charges. Lisa Boothe is a senior fellow at Independent Women's Voice and she's followed this closely.

utterances.speaker: LISA BOOTHE, INDEPENDENT WOMEN'S VOICE
utterances.sentences: Hey, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Lisa, what -- well tell me about her conclusions.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Well her conclusions, as you stated, I mean basically she goes through all these various inconsistencies that we've seen with Christine stories -- Ford's story. But the problem is she's basically remained unquestioned by the media and the Left and that's dangerous because if you're bringing life altering and life ruining accusations against someone, your story should be questioned. You go through the inconsistencies. One, every witness that Christine Ford has named has denied the event in question. You go back and looking at the fact, she's different -- given different periods of time. She texted The Washington Post, mid-1980s. And then she comes to the conclusion in The Washington Post article it was the summer of 1982, she's given different stories about how many people were there. And her polygraph letter alone, she has two different versions. Originally, four people crossed off, and then it's four boys, two girls. And then even if you want to give her the benefit of the doubt of oh, that's -- it was 36 years ago, maybe her memory's just not straight, then you go to the recent problems. She said she doesn't remember how The Washington Post got her therapist. No, it's yet The Washington Post says that she -- she provided them to her. She can't remember when she had the polygraph test. Whereas this complete farce from her and her attorneys about being afraid to fly, then it turns out she's flied to Hawaii, Costa reach -- Rica, French Polynesia, so we have seen all these inconsistencies not just with long-term memory but also with recent. However, nobody's called her on and I think--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: --the reason being is everybody is so afraid of the MeToo movement, so afraid of these bullies on the Left that they're afraid to call a spade of -- a spade.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: And she's not credible. Her story doesn't add up. And Rachel Mitchell, this memo I think just completely lays all the facts bare.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's amazing. You've been great on this from the very beginning--

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and thank you for your bravery. The whole country is afraid. This was not the country we were promised.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: We were terrified to say what you think or to be reasonable. And I -- I hope this ends soon.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: I have three brothers and a dad.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: And so I think about that and I think it's important.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's bad for all of us, men and women. Lisa, thank you.

utterances.speaker: BOOTHE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Having received the FBI investigation they demanded, Democrats now say it's not enough. They want a bigger investigation that goes on forever. Jeff Flake is really surprised by this. He thought it was just a week. Is anyone else surprised? That's next.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well having convinced poor Jeff Flake to order a week-long FBI investigation of Judge Brett Kavanaugh that happened after someone screamed at him in an elevator, which is how our democracy works now, Democrats are now trying to dictate the scope of the investigation as if they're in charge of Congress, which, thanks to Jeff Flake, functionally they are. In a letter released today, 10 Democrats in the Senate Judiciary Committee have called for the Bureau to investigate all three allegations against Kavanaugh including Julie Swetnick's fantasy about gang-rape. Their letter also lists 24 people they would like interviewed at a bare minimum about their allegations. Jonathan Turley is Professor at Georgetown University Law School and he joins us tonight. Professor, thanks for coming on. So it -- are we right to feel a little bit misled when Democrats in public told us just on Friday, it's now Monday, so three days later that they wanted just Christine Ford's allegations investigated for a week, and now the goalposts are so far down the field we can't see them. Should we feel like we've been lied to?

utterances.speaker: JONATHAN TURLEY, GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY LAW SCHOOL
utterances.sentences: Well I think that the least convincing part of the Democratic case is that this was not being manipulated in terms of its timing. I think most people believe that this -- these allegations were held to the last minute right before a vote. And I think there's some legitimate criticism for that. And also, I think you -- one can anticipate that one week is not going to satisfy many of the critics. The fact is that that most of these statements, if not all of them, were previously given to the committee. They're unlikely to change. And so, the outcome of this investigation is unlikely to change many minds. And we're going to get to a point where we have to make a decision. If Senators feel that the record is insufficient, they have a reason, I suppose, to vote on that basis. But to keep this open indefinitely is going to do, I think, an injustice to the nominee and to the process. So, we have to come to some conclusion.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, Julie Swetnick's claims that there was a series of at least 10 gang-rapes that took place in public of children sometime in the early 1980s outside Washington, no one's ever heard this before, it's never been alleged before, do you think this rises to the level of credibility that would spur an FBI investigation almost 40 years later?

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: It sounds like the FBI is not going to investigate that allegation. Part of the concern for many people is that this is an extraordinary allegation with -- with it and no one going to the police previously or any accounts being published as to what occurred. And I, it's -- for that reason, I think that the FBI is focusing on the other -- the earlier two allegations.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Huh? Do you expect that Republicans will be able to reassert control over this process since I think they do run the United States Senate? Could they say, you know--

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: Ha-ha. Ha-ha.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it's been enough time. We, you know, it's been -- Mark Judge has been interviewed, again, under oath. And we're done. Can they do that?

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: Of course, they can. And it does appear that McConnell was going to push this through. He insists that there's going to be a vote this week. The timing is a little bit curious because the FBI was given a full week that would end on Friday. Presumably, a lot of material would be given to the Senate on Friday. So it's not quite clear how the logistics are going to happen for the FBI to be concluded on Friday, presumably, and also have the vote on Friday.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. Professor Turley, thanks very much. It's great to talk to you- -

utterances.speaker: TURLEY
utterances.sentences: Thank you. See you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --as always.  Are Democrats using delaying tactics against Kavanaugh? Senator Tom Cotton is a Republican. He represents the State of Arkansas and he joins us tonight. Senator, thanks very much for coming on and I mean that because we've been trying to get any Republican from the U.S. Senate to come on and make the affirmative case for Judge Kavanaugh for two weeks now, and you're the only one who said "Yes." I'm watching another side an army of surrogates go out to call him a sex offender. Why are you the only Republican who's willing to come on TV to make the case for Kavanaugh?

utterances.speaker: SEN. TOM COTTON, R-ARK.
utterances.sentences: Tucker, it is pretty one-sided out here that army of surrogates needs to get a lot bigger if they're going to take me on because it's very easy to defend Judge Kavanaugh. He have a -- has a stellar record on the bench. He has a long and distinguished history of public service. And he has undergone six background checks, Tucker, six background checks.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: He has.

utterances.speaker: COTTON
utterances.sentences: And now, somehow, the FBI is supposed to turn up new information in just a few days to satisfy all the Democrats. Yet, as soon as we agreed to have a limited investigation by the FBI into current credible allegations of which I would say there are none, but to humor them, to give them a few days, they immediately started moving the goalposts saying that we have to interview two dozen witnesses, and has to take weeks and on and on and on. It's never going to end, Tucker. This is not about trying to get the facts or get the proof. It's about trying to stop Brett Kavanaugh from being confirmed to the Supreme Court, that all comes to an end this week, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: What I find so striking is that he's a sitting federal judge who's authored scores and scores of opinions. And yet we're not debating any of them. His judicial philosophy is not even up for debate. It's all about his high school yearbook. Does it strike you this conversation is unbecoming of a country as advanced as ours? It's just so stupefyingly dumb. Why?

utterances.speaker: COTTON
utterances.sentences: It is -- it is pretty amusing to see Democratic senators poring over a high school yearbook as if it were the da Vinci Code, Tucker--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COTTON
utterances.sentences: --and hypocritical of senators like Amy Klobuchar who are condemning Brett Kavanaugh for uncorroborated allegations from 36 years ago. Yet, Amy Klobuchar stands by Keith Ellison who stands credibly accused of beating his ex-girlfriend just a few years ago with contemporaneous medical and police records. It just goes to show you that the Democrats are engaged in an orchestrated smear campaign to assassinate Brett Kavanaugh's character--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COTTON
utterances.sentences: --because they'll stop at nothing to prevent him from getting on the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Finally, a U.S. Senator to make the case -- and a -- and a -- and very ably made. Thank you very much, Senator. Good to see you.

utterances.speaker: COTTON
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Nancy Pelosi says that whether the party succeeds or fails in keeping Brett Kavanaugh off the Supreme Court, they're going to try to impeach him if they win in mid-terms. That is next.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Democrats doing their best to stop Brett Kavanaugh's nomination and destroy his reputation, they may win at that, they may fail. Either way, they're not giving up. Nancy Pelosi says that even if the Democrats win control of the Congress, they're ready to impeach Kavanaugh.

utterances.speaker: HOUSE MINORITY LEADER NANCY PELOSI, D-CALIF.
utterances.sentences: If Judge Kavanaugh, see I'm being really spec, President Trump, Judge Kavanaugh, if -- if they -- if he is not telling the truth to Congress, or to the FBI, then he's not fit not only to be on the Supreme Court but to being the -- on the court that he's on right now.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: She didn't specify what court he's on right now. But that was the future Speaker of the House, perhaps, Nancy Pelosi. Rochelle Ritchie is a former Press Secretary for the House Democrats and she joins us tonight. Thanks a lot for coming on.

utterances.speaker: ROCHELLE RITCHIE, FORMER PRESS SECRETARY, HOUSE DEMOCRATIC POLICY AND COMMUNICATIONS COMMITTEE
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Tucker. Thanks for having me.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So, look, I know I've got a position on this. But do you really think it's wise to create a system where even if you lose your effort to stop someone from getting on to a court that you will impeach him once he gets on the court?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Well look, I think that there's a lot of hypocrisy right now coming from Conservatives. And the reason I -- why I say that is because they're literally outraged right now and pushing to have Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein fired for unsubstantiated comments. And yet, they religiously stand behind Judge Brett Kavanaugh. So as--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I'm not sure I'm tracking your logic. What do you--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: What do you mean?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --what, fired for unsubstantiated comments, which one?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: The comments about recording Donald Trump, those comments.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well for whatever it's worth, I'm not calling for Rosenstein to be fired and I'm --

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: You're not. But there are -- but there are 11 --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --just the opposite. But even I don't like Rod Rosenstein but it would be a little weird if Republicans said, well Rod Rosenstein should be, I don't know if he could be impeached, but impeached?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --fired. That he'd be fired--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, fired--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --and you have a 11 Republicans right now pushing for that. But I think that we do have to listen and understand what Pelosi is saying. If this man is not qualified because of his temperament to be a Supreme Court Justice, then why will we not question whether or not he should be on the Supreme Court?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I think it's totally fair to question whether he should be on the Supreme Court--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: We agree then --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --but that's not what she said. Well, of course, I mean I -- I believe in questions. I do it for a living. It's the Left. It's always denouncing me for asking obvious questions. But let me just ask you this.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: I'm not denouncing you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well here is an obvious question. On what grounds would he be impeached, removed from the bench? What will be the argument? What will be the crime?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Well I think that with any one, well see, there is no crime, is he ? I think that's the problem that's happening with Conservatives is that -- is that they're looking at this as a criminal trial.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: No, but hold on wait, no, no, but doesn't impeachment by definition requires a crime, I believe.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: I would not --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I mean so impeachment is a process of putting someone on trial--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Well I -- I think--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --removing him by the Congress.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --I think that what -- what they're saying is it's going to depend on what comes out of the FBI investigation, obviously. If there is an FBI investigation, which I don't think this is a criminal investigation--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's not.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --and that's why I was saying this is not a trial. There's no jury, judge, prosecutor, or public defender.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right. But in --

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: This is about character references.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: And if those references don't pan out, just like with anyone else in the United States, you don't get hired, or as Trump says, you get fired.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. I -- I get it. But that's not what Pelosi's arguing. And it may be that Nancy Pelosi doesn't understand the system. She seemed odd in the clip, I will say--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: I think she understands. I think she understands the system.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --well then -- then impeachment, I believe, requires a crime. She said if he lied -- if he lied under oath. What would he have lied about? And how would we know that? I mean--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --what is she talking about actually?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --well, he could have lied about sexually assaulting Dr. Ford. He could have lied about--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: And that can be proved how?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: We'll have to see what comes out of the FBI investigation.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Do you think if it -- so he said that he didn't drink that much in high school, in college, and Democrats seem very eager to prove that he did. Are you comfortable with that as a line of argument that 37 years--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --after the fact sitting United States senators could make it their single-minded focus to show that you drank more beer than you said you did? Or does that degrade our system a little bit to have a conversation that stupid?

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't think that it's a stupid conversation. I think it's a very serious conversation because we are talking about sexual assault. And those comments have been backed up by college peers of his -- his that he went to at the university --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So is that the so the standard is--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --and they're not claiming that he hurt anyone--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --he had one woman call him a sloppy drunk.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: OK. That -- that's great. This is this -- this is the party of Ted Kennedy saying that if you drink too much you're not suited for high office. Is that the argument they're making in college--

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: No. The argument is is that if you are accused of sexual assault then you are not fit to sit on the Supreme Court.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: They're not and that -- and that's a fine standard. But they're not making that argument. They're saying his friends from college say he drank too much.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: I don't think that that is necessarily the complete--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: You don't --

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: --argument, Tucker. I think that's part of it as far as his character --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well no one from college has said that he -- that he sexually assaulted anybody. I haven't seen that -- even that allegation.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: But we do have an allegation that's coming from Dr. Ford right now. And we have to let the FBI do their investigation to get to the bottom of it--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right. Well they are. They are and -- and it's going to take a couple years apparently according to Senate Democrats to get that done.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: A couple of years ?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I don't know. It was supposed to take a week. It's all such a scam --

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Have well --

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much Rochelle for joining us.

utterances.speaker: RITCHIE
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Tucker. Thanks.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Nice to -- nice to see you. Kirsten Gillibrand is bringing a new brand of justice to America where an accusation is the same as guilt. That's not the country we grew up in. How do you feel about living in it now? That's next.

utterances.speaker: TEXT
utterances.sentences: TUCKER'S BOOK IS OUT TOMORROW.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well Brett Kavanaugh's show trial is disturbing enough on its own terms, all these pompous know-nothings going on about stupid things. But worse than that, it appears to herald a new era in American justice, a time whose foremost prophet is turning out to be Senator Kirsten Gillibrand of New York. In this new world, a person is guilty as soon as accused of any crime. Questioning an accuser isn't a constitutional right. Instead, it's a crime. Michael Anton is a Research Fellow at Hillsdale College. He's former National Security Official in the Trump Administration. And he just wrote a piece on this new Gillibrand standard. He joins us tonight. Michael Anton, thank you very much for coming on. What is the Gillibrand standard you wrote about?

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL ANTON, LECTURER AND RESEARCH FELLOW, HILLSDALE COLLEGE
utterances.sentences: It is as you've said and as your last guest said. It is that in certain cases, the accusation suffices to convict that, you know, further investigation, presumption of innocence, right to confront accusers, none of that matters. The -- the accuser raises the hand and says, I say this, and we're all obligated to accept it. Now, the Democrats, I think, in their defense would say, well this isn't a trial. It's not a criminal trial. In this case, the Judge is seeking a -- a great thing, a seat on the Supreme Court that no one is entitled to, so we don't need to be held to these niceties of law. But once they've set this standard, essentially, if this precedent is allowed to hold, what will happen is any citizen of the United States will have an effective veto power over any member of any court or the cabinet. All they have to do is come forward and say, "I accuse you of something 30 years ago. You can't question my sincerity. The accusation is enough to sow doubt, therefore you -- you have to step down." In the piece, I described it as essentially akin to, you know, being in a - - a sporting event, you know, going up to your opponent before the thing with a baseball bat breaking his arm and then saying "Well, too bad you can't play. I guess you got to forfeit and let me win."

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes, it's not a--

utterances.speaker: ANTON
utterances.sentences: I mean that needs some help too.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --it's not a criminal trial. So, why do you have a problem with that? I mean I guess what I find so striking is the idea that those standards only applies in a strict legal setting, those are the standards of fairness that apply to all human interaction including the way you parent your children. Since when do they not count?

utterances.speaker: ANTON
utterances.sentences: Since the Supreme Court is divided five to four, and since this has become, as you say, a completely politicized event, and there was nothing in Brett Kavanaugh's record as a judge to sow any doubt about his qualifications. In fact, his qualifications, as you've pointed out many times, are beyond sterling. So, the Democrats were clearly looking at a -- a loss here. Brett Kavanaugh was going to get confirmed. They had to do something, so they came up with this. I think it sets a disastrous precedent for our country--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: ANTON
utterances.sentences: --it's also cruelly unfair to him and to his family.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: --well it's -- it's awful. But what does it say, quickly, about the people doing it? If you say in public that fairness doesn't matter what does that say about you?

utterances.speaker: ANTON
utterances.sentences: That power is everything. All that matters is winning in the here and now. Collateral damage to institutions--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: ANTON
utterances.sentences: --doesn't matter. Damage to people, damage to families, damage to little kids doesn't matter, none of that matters. The only thing that matters is power, holding on to it, gaining more of it.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, it's a secular worldview, I would say. Michael, thank you very much, great to see you.

utterances.speaker: ANTON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: The Deputy Chairman of the DNC, Keith Ellison, has been cleared by his own party because they say the woman accusing him doesn't have videotape. Therefore, who cares what she says? Huh. We'll get more on that case next.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Democratic Party has finally finished its long-awaited probe of the Deputy Chairman of the DNC, Keith Ellison. Its law firm says the allegations against Ellison can't be substantiated because the accuser doesn't have videotape, so they're ignoring her word. That would be called victim-shaming under other circumstances. Karin Housley is a State Senator, a Republican, U.S. Senate candidate from Minnesota and she joins us tonight. Karin, are you happy with this new standard that the DNC has articulated?

utterances.speaker: KARIN HOUSLEY, AMERICAN POLITICIAN, REPUBLICAN MEMBER, MINNESOTA SENATE
utterances.sentences: No. And thank you so much for having me, Tucker. It just shows the hypocrisy of the Democrat Party and the double standard that they do have. I'm running for the hashtag MeToo Al Franken seat for the U.S. Senate in Minnesota. And my opponent is still out there campaigning with them and she says that Keith Alex -- Ellison categorically denies these allegations. Therefore, she believes them and she stands with them. Yet, when it's Brett Kavanaugh, a Republican, they want a full and complete investigation. So, it just shows the hypocrisies that and the investigation that was done was done of Keith Ellison, who was the Vice Chair of the DNC Party--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HOUSLEY
utterances.sentences: --done by the law firm of a Democrat of the Democrat Party in Minnesota. So, it's like the fox watching the henhouse. So it -- and it's Karen Monahan, the Keith Ellison's former girlfriend, she's out on Twitter again tonight, and I've retweeted it. She's -- she's begging for somebody to listen to her. But the Democrats and the complete hypocrisy that they are -- that they are, aren't listening to her.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: So look, I have no idea if the allegations are correct or not. I - - I really don't know and I would withhold judgment because I think that's what fair people would do. But I'm surprised by the reaction. Have the press in Minnesota, the paper there in the Twin Cities, for example, been hounding Keith Ellison to explain what exactly this is about?

utterances.speaker: HOUSLEY
utterances.sentences: No, absolutely not. It is dead silence among the media and the Democrats in Minnesota. Yet, all we hear about is Brett -- Brett Kavanaugh and how we should have a full FBI investigation. But the media is quiet. And my opponent, Tina Smith, again, out there fully campaigning and supporting Keith Ellison, and nobody, nobody is bringing these accusations, are calling for an invest -- investigation, so I did. Today, I called on the Attorney General of Minnesota to do a full investigation of Keith Ellison because the voters of Minnesota, they want to know before they go to the polls in November who is Keith Ellison and -- and he's -- has he really done these things to his girlfriend?

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: But I -- I mean I can't keep up with what the rules are because they change so often. But quickly, aren't we supposed to believe the woman? I keep hearing that.

utterances.speaker: HOUSLEY
utterances.sentences: You know, I -- sexual harassment abuse, domestic abuse it is all wrong. And every accuser should be heard--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HOUSLEY
utterances.sentences: --because and -- and against Keith Ellison, these are some really, really serious accusations--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: HOUSLEY
utterances.sentences: --but nobody is listening -- nobody is listening to Karen Monahan- -

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: It's -- it's only about power.

utterances.speaker: HOUSLEY
utterances.sentences: --so I am, I'm--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Karin, thank you.

utterances.speaker: HOUSLEY
utterances.sentences: --it's only about power and it's--

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HOUSLEY
utterances.sentences: --yes, thank you, Tucker.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Wish we had more time. Great to see you. Thank you very much. I'm not great at selling things, which is why I haven't been talking about this book every night for the past year. But it's coming out tomorrow and I'm proud of it because I think it tells the story. It explains what has happened in this country, how President Trump was elected, why, and how the battleground seems to have shifted so completely? If people you're watching on television were saying one thing 10 years ago and saying the opposite tonight, and you are seeing that, this book explains why. It's out tomorrow. Hope you buy it. It's great, I think. That's it for us tonight. See you tomorrow on the show that is the sworn enemy of lying, pomposity, smugness and groupthink. We're live in New York tonight. Sean Hannity is live in our studio in Washington. Hey, Sean.

utterances.speaker: SEAN HANNITY, FOX NEWS
utterances.sentences: Hey, I'm in your studio. By the way, and you get to be a guest on my show coming up later tonight. I give - - give you time to breathe and collect yourself after a great show. Good show tonight.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Sean.

utterances.speaker: HANNITY
utterances.sentences: Congrats on the new book, by the way.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Content and Programming Copyright 2018 Fox News Network, LLC. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED. Copyright 2018 CQ-Roll Call, Inc.
